QuestionText: A satellite is moving in a circular orbit at a certain height above the Earth's surface. It is found that the time period of the satellite is $T$. If the satellite is brought to an orbit of smaller radius, its time period will:
explanationText: According to Kepler's third law of planetary motion, the square of the time period of revolution of a satellite ($T^2$) is directly proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis of its orbit ($R^3$). So, $T^2 \propto R^3$. If the radius $R$ decreases, the time period $T$ will also decrease.

QuestionText: The value of acceleration due to gravity ($g$) at a height $h$ above the surface of the Earth is given by $g' = g(1 - 2h/R)$, where $R$ is the radius of the Earth. This formula is valid when:
explanationText: The exact formula for acceleration due to gravity at height $h$ is $g' = gR^2 / (R+h)^2 = g(1 + h/R)^{-2}$. Using binomial expansion for $(1+x)^n \approx 1+nx$ when $x << 1$, we get $g' \approx g(1 - 2h/R)$. This approximation is valid only when $h << R$.
